facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Decree dated 12th March 1951 of Calcutta High Court by Harries J. and Banerjee J.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th March, 1951, of the High Court of judicature at Calcutta  Harries J. and Banerjee J.

facts.text: Appeal from Original Decree dated 21st March 1950 of Calcutta High Court in Suit No. 1112 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Decree dated the 21st March, 1950, of the Calcutta High Court in its ordinary original civil jurisdiction in Suit No. 1112 of 1946.

facts.text: Suit No. 1112 of 1946 commenced by Central National Bank Limited in Original Side of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit,. out of which this appeal arises, was companymenced by the Central National Bank Limited, the appellant before us, in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court,

facts.text: Bank sought declaration of rights as pledgee of two blocks of shares in Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. and Steel Corporation of Bengal Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that the bank acquired the rights of a pledgee in respect of two blocks Of shares in two companypanies, to wit, the Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. and the Steel Corporation of Bengal Ltd.

facts.text: Shares numbered 800 and were property of Radhika Mohan Bhuiya, defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: and was e entitled to sell the shares in enforcement of the pledge. There was a claim for recovery of possession of these shares and also for, damages alleged to have been suffered by the plaintiff by reason of wrongful denial of its title by the defendant Bank. The shares, to which the dispute relates, are 800 in number and admittedly they were the property of one Radhika Mohan Bhuiya, the defendant No. 2 in the suit.

facts.text: In February 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell shares to Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in February, 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell these shares to one Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for the price of Rs. 38,562-8-0.

facts.text: On 14th February 1946, Bhuiya sent shares and transfer deeds to defendant bank with instructions to deliver against payment.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th February, 1946, Bhuiya sent these shares along with the relative transfer deeds to the defendant bank with instructions to deliver over the share certificates and the transfer deeds to the purchaser, against payment of the entire companysideration money stated above.

facts.text: On 18th February 1946, defendant bank directed Nilkrishna Paul to deliver shares to Mukherjee after receiving pay order for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th of February following, the defendant bank directed one of its officers, to wit, Nilkrishna Paul, to see Mukherjee at his office and hand over to him the shares after receiving from him a pay order for the sum of Rs. 38,562-8-0 signed by the Punjab National Bank.

facts.text: Paul met Mukherjee at his chamber about 11 a.m. on 18th February 1946.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this direction, Paul went to the ,office of Mukherjee and saw him at his chamber at about 11 a.m. in the morning.

facts.text: Mukherjee examined shares and transfer deeds, then left with them saying he was going to get the pay order and would return.

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjee asked for the shares, but Paul refused to make over the share certificates to him unless the pay order was given Mukherjee then said that he wanted to have a look at the shares and the transfer deeds just to satisfy himself that they were all right. After that Paul placed the shares and the transfer deeds on the table. Mukherjee examined the share certificates one after another and when he was about to leave the chamber along with the share certificates and the ranK transfer deeds, Paul raised an objection and asked him number to go away without giving him the pay order. Mukherjee then said to Paul I am going out to get the pay order it is ready. You take your seat I am companying. With these words Mukherjee went out of his chamber and did number return thereafter.

facts.text: Mukherjee pledged shares to plaintiff bank, receiving advance of Rs. 29,000.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he went straight to the office of the plaintiff bank and pledged the shares with it, taking an advance of Rs. 29,000 in terms of an agreement which was previously arrived at between them.

facts.text: Mukherjee opened account with Rs.100 cheque, got overdraft of Rs.29,000, executed promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: What happened in substance was this Mukherjee gave a cheque for Rs. 100 with which an account in Ms name was opened for the first time with the plaintiff bank, and the advance of Rs. 29,000 was given to Mukherjee by way of overdraft on this current account. Mukherjee also executed a promissory numbere for the said amount in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Mukherjee has not been heard of since and whereabouts unknown.

anchor.surface_text: It is, the companymon case of the parties that Mukherjee has number been heard of since then and his present whereabouts are unknown.

facts.text: Paul waited then reported to superior, police complaint lodged by defendant bank.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to Paul, the defendants, officer, after waiting vainly for Mukherjee he had numberother alternative but to companye back to his office and inform his superior officer of all that had happened. A companyplaint was then lodged with the police on behalf of the defendant bank.

facts.text: Mukherjee's Rs.100 cheque to plaintiff dishonored.

anchor.surface_text: The cheque, which was given to the plaintiff by Mukherjee, was dishonored when it was presented for payment.

facts.text: Plaintiff sold shares through broker Jalan, received Rs.16,000 cheque which was stopped, police took possession of shares.

anchor.surface_text: As numberreply came from Mukherjee, the plaintiff sold these shares through a broker named jalan. jalan took delivery of the shares and gave the plaintiff a cheque for Rs. 16,000 in part payment of the price. The payment of the cheque, however, was stopped and the police, who had already taken the matter in hand, took possession of the shares.

facts.text: Criminal case against Shaw, accomplice of Mukherjee, unsuccessful, Shaw acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: As Mukherjee companyld number be traced, a criminal case was started against an alleged accomplice of his, named Shaw, but this proved unsuccessful and Shaw was acquitted.

facts.text: Defendant bank paid full price to Bhuiya.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant bank, who had paid the full price of these shares to Bhuiya, then presented an application to the Magistrate,

facts.text: Defendant bank applied to Magistrate for return of shares as owner.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant bank, who had paid the full price of these shares to Bhuiya, then presented an application to the Magistrate, praying that the shares might be returned to it on the ground of its being the owner thereof.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit upon learning of defendant's application.

anchor.surface_text: On getting information of this application, the plaintiff bank instituted the present suit, the allegation in substance being that the plaintiff being the pledge of the shares was entitled, in law, to the possession thereof.

facts.text: Bhuiya had no further interest as paid off by defendant bank.

anchor.surface_text: As has been stated already, Bhuiya, having been paid off by the defendant bank, had numberfurther interest in the litigation. The fight was thus entirely between the two banks.

facts.text: Mukherjee did not acquire legal title to shares; only agreement for sale, property passes on payment.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that Mukherjee did number acquire any legal title to the shares. There was only an agreement for sale between him and Bhuiya, and under the terms of,the companytract the property in the shares companyld number pass to him till the price was paid.

facts.text: Trial judge Mr. Justice Sarkar decreed in favor of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Sarkar of the Calcutta High Court, who tried the suit, decided this question in favour of the plaintiff. The learned judge was of opinion that Mukherjee had obtained possession of the shares with the companysent of Bhuiya or rather his agent, the bank officer, within the meaning of section 30  2 , Indian Sale of Goods Act,

facts.text: Appellate bench of Harries CJ and Banerjee J reversed trial court on 12 March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal by the defendant against this judgment which was heard by a bench companysisting of Trevor Harries C. J. and Banerjee J. The learned judges allowed the appeal and reversed the judgment of the trial companyrt holding that the defendants agent never companysented to Mukherjees obtaining possession of the shares as buyer.

provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, the language of which is as follows - Where a person, having bought or agreed to buy goods, obtains, with the companysent of the seller, possession of the goods or the documents of title to the goods, the delivery or transfer by that person or by a mercantile agent acting for him, of the goods or documents of title under any sale, pledge or other disposition thereof to any person receiving the same in good faith and without numberice of any lien or other right of the original seller in respect of the goods shall have effect as if such lien or right did number exist.

concepts.interpretation: Requires buyer to obtain possession with seller's consent; protects good faith transferee/pledgee; consent determined by Contract Act s13; fraud generally makes voidable only, not negating consent unless void ab initio (e.g., identity error); criminal intent or English larceny by trick does not negate owner's consent.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of Goods Act, the language of which is as follows - Where a person, having bought or agreed to buy goods, obtains, with the companysent of the seller

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 30(2) Indian Sale of Goods Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Exception to nemo dat; disposition by buyer in possession with seller consent binds seller against good faith recipient.

The learned judge was of opinion that Mukherjee had obtained possession of the shares with the companysent of Bhuiya or rather his agent, the bank officer, within the meaning of section 30  2 , Indian Sale of Goods Act,

There was numberintention to give delivery at all. It was Mukherjee who took the shares and bolted and his act was as much theft as if he had taken them out of Nilkrishna Pauls pocket.

issues.text: whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the defendant bank on the other hand was that Mukherjee was number in possession of the Shares with the companysent of the seller, number was the plaintiff a bona fide pledgee without numberice of thedefect of title. The whole companytroversy thus centeredround the point as to whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act.

issues.text: whether the companysent necessary under section 30 2  of the Sale of Goods Act must be a free companysent uninfluenced by fraud or false representation

anchor.surface_text: The two principal questions that require companysideration are first, whether the companysent necessary under section 30 2  of the Sale of Goods Act must be a free companysent uninfluenced by fraud or false representation, and secondly, whether the existence of such companysent is negatived, as a matter of law,

issues.text: whether the existence of such companysent is negatived, as a matter of law, it a person of the requisite description mentioned in the section obtains possession of goods from the owner by trick or other deceitful means which makes his act punishable as a crime

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, whether the existence of such companysent is negatived, as a matter of law, it a person of the requisite description mentioned in the section obtains possession of goods from the owner by trick or other deceitful means which makes his act punishable as a crime. There is numberdecision on these points by any High Court in. India

arguments.claim: Plaintiff entitled to protection under section 30(2) SOGA: valid sale contract, good faith pledgee, possession obtained with consent per section 13 Indian Contract Act; fraud immaterial, no criminal law principles

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . A companysent induced byfalse representation may number be free, but it can nevertheless be real, and ordinarily the effect of fraud or misrepresent

arguments.court_reasoning: Legal principles on consent accepted (fraud doesn't negate), but rejected on facts: no consent given

arguments.claim: On facts, no consent by defendant's agent to Mukherjee obtaining possession

The dispute between them... is mainly on the point as to whether, on the facts of the case, it could be held that Mukherjee got possession

court_response_anchor.surface_text: kherjee went out of the room with the shares in his hand, he undoubtedly got possession of the shares but on the evidence on the record, we do number

arguments.court_reasoning: Paul objected to Mukherjee leaving with shares without payment

arguments.claim: Consent under SOGA 30(2) means consent per ICA s13; need not be free consent per ICA s14; fraud makes voidable, protects innocent pledgee

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned counsel on both sides that the word consent as used in section 30  2  of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing on the same thinging the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act... Section 14 of the Contract Act defines theexpression free consent

arguments.claim: Fraudulently induced consent sufficient under SOGA 30(2) unless void ab initio (e.g., identity fraud); protects innocent transferee

anchor.surface_text: A consent induced byfalse representation may not be free, but it can nevertheless be real... If an innocent purchaser or pledgee obtains goods from the person in possession thereof, whose possessory right is, defeasible on the ground of fraud but had not actually been defeated

arguments.claim: Criminal intent or larceny by trick does not negate owner's consent under SOGA 30(2); distinguish from English criminal fictions; follow contract principles

anchor.surface_text: obtaining possession of goods by false pretences does not exclude the operation of the Factors Act in England and in our opinion it does not exclude the operation of section 30 2  of the Sale of Goods Act in India... no justification for importing a highly technical rule of English criminal law

arguments.claim: On facts, Mukherjee did not obtain possession with consent of seller's agent Paul; Paul protested and did not assent to taking shares

anchor.surface_text: When Mukherjee went out of the room with the shares in his hand, he undoubtedly got possession of the shares but on the evidence on the record, we do not think it possible to hold that he got possession with the consent of Paul. The evidence shows that Paul actually protested

holdings.text: The word consent as used in section 30(2) of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing on the same thing in the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned counsel on both sides that the word consent as used in section 30 2 of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing on the same thinging the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act. There is no definition of consent in the Sale of Goods Act itself,

holdings.reasoning_summary: By virtue of section 2(15) SOGA, undefined terms take meaning from Indian Contract Act; both parties agree.

holdings.text: Consent under section 30(2) SOGA need not be free consent under section 14 ICA; consent induced by fraud or misrepresentation is real consent making transaction voidable, not void.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Contract Act defines the expression free consent and a consent is free when it is not caused by coercion, under influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. A consent induced by false representation may not be free, but it can nevertheless be real,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes free consent from real consent; protects innocent transferee before avoidance; supported by English authorities like Cahn and Pearson.

holdings.text: Fraud negates consent under section 30(2) SOGA only if it renders transfer void ab initio, such as error in identity of person; otherwise, voidable fraud allows protection to good faith pledgee.

anchor.surface_text: The position, however, is entirely different if the fraud committed is of such a character as would prevent there being consent at all on the part of the owner to give possession of the goods to a particular person. Thus A might obtain possession of goods from the owner by falsely representing himself to be B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Real consent requires consensus ad idem; identity fraud prevents agreement (Lake v Simmons); ordinary fraud voidable only.

holdings.text: Obtaining possession by trick, deceit, or criminal means does not negate consent under section 30(2) SOGA as matter of law; English criminal law fictions like larceny by trick not imported into Indian commercial law.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to what has been said above, this question should not present any difficulty... Even if the owner was induced to part with the goods by fraudulent misrepresentation he must yet be held to have consented to give possession and the fact that the receiver had a dishonest intention... no justification for importing a highly technical rule of English criminal law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent determined by owner's state of mind per contract law, not recipient's criminal intent; distinguishes Folkes v King, rejects larceny distinctions; first Indian clarification, no HC precedent.

holdings.text: Mukherjee did not obtain possession of the shares with the consent of the seller's agent Paul; Paul protested and did not assent to Mukherjee taking the shares away.

anchor.surface_text: When Mukherjee went out of the room with the shares in his hand, he undoubtedly got possession of the shares but on the evidence on the record, we do not think it possible to hold that he got possession with the consent of Paul. The evidence shows that Paul actually protested

holdings.reasoning_summary: Paul placed shares for inspection only, objected to removal without payment, did not rely on Mukherjee's promise as he waited briefly then searched; no assent given.

holdings.text: Plaintiff bank not entitled to protection under section 30(2) SOGA as Mukherjee lacked seller's consent to possession.

anchor.surface_text: The whole question is, whether Mukherjee got possession of the shares with the consent of the seller, and it is not disputed that the consent of the defendants clerk, who was acting as the agent of the owner, would be as effective as the consent of the owner himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No consent on facts precludes application of exception to nemo dat; affirms appellate High Court reversal of trial court.

precedents.citation: Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company 1

anchor.surface_text: In Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company 1 , Collins J. made the following oftquoted observation - However fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been, in obtaining the possession, provided it does number amount to larceny by trick

precedents.case_name: Cahn v Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company
precedents.cited_proposition: fraudulent possession does not prevent giving good title to innocent purchaser unless larceny by trick
precedents.cited_holding: However fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been, in obtaining the possession, provided it does number amount to larceny by trick [...] he can, by his disposition, give a good title to the purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The law on this point has been thus summed up by Denning L. J. in Pearson v. Rose 3  The effect of fraud is as a rule only to make the transaction voidable and number void, and if,. therefore, an innocent purchaser has bought the goods before the transaction is avoided the true owner cannot claim them back.

precedents.cited_proposition: fraud makes transaction voidable, not void; innocent purchaser protected if before avoidance
precedents.cited_holding: The effect of fraud is as a rule only to make the transaction voidable and number void [...] then the owner cannot claim the goods back from an innocent purchaser who has bought them in good faith from the mercantile agent

anchor.surface_text: In Lake v. Simmons 1  Lord Haldane made the following observations while dealing with a similar point The appellant thought that he was dealing with a different person, the wife of Van der Borgh, and it was on that footing alone that he parted with the goods.

precedents.cited_proposition: no consent where fraud as to identity of person
precedents.cited_holding: There was number the agreement of her mind with that of the seller that was required [...] The latter was entirely deceived as to the identity of the person with whom he was transacting.

anchor.surface_text: as was said by Bankes L. J. in Folkes v. King 1 , that is altogether immaterial for the purpose of determining whether there was companysent on the part of the owner of the goods under the Factors Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: dishonest intention of receiver immaterial for owner's consent under Factors Act
precedents.cited_holding: the two companysiderations [criminal intent and consent] should be kept entirely distinct

anchor.surface_text: Vide Whitehorn v. Davison 1911 1 K.B. 463, 479. With regard to the first category of cases,however, the decisions of the English companyrts are number at all uniform.

precedents.cited_proposition: larceny by trick where no real consent due to misrepresentation of identity or goods

precedents.citation: Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: As has been said already, Collins J. in Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel etc. 1  made the observation that however fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been in obtaining possession, provided it did number amount to larceny by trick he can by his disposition give a good title.

precedents.case_name: Cahn v Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company
precedents.cited_proposition: fraudulent obtaining of possession allows good title unless larceny by trick

anchor.surface_text: The observation as regards the exception in case of larceny by trick, though it companyld number rank higher than an obiter, was accepted as good law by the Court of Appeal in England in Oppenheimer v. Frazer 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: accepted exception for larceny by trick (obiter from Cahn)

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was held by Bankes L. J. and and Scrutton L. J. in Folkes v. King 3  that when companysent was In fact given by the owner of the goods, it was immaterial that the receiver was guilty of larceny by trick,

precedents.cited_proposition: consent in fact given is not negated by larceny by trick

anchor.surface_text: and this view was approved of by the majority of the Court of Appeal in Lake v. Simmons 4 , though Atkin L. J. delivered a dissenting judgment The decision in Lake v. Simmons

precedents.cited_proposition: approved Folkes view in Court of Appeal

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Lake v. Simmons 4  was reversed by the House of Lords 5  but their Lordships proceeded number on any technical doctrine of criminal law but on the broad ground which we have already discussed that there was a mistake fatal to there being a companysenting mind at all.

precedents.cited_proposition: reversed on ground of no consensus ad idem due to identity mistake, not criminal law technicality

anchor.surface_text: The view taken in Folkes v. King 3  has been approved of in the recent decision of Pearson v. Rose 6 . Thus, to quote the language of Lord Sumner, there is a signal and indecisive companyflict of authoritative opinion on this point 7 .

precedents.citation: Lake v. Simmons 1927 A. C. 487 at 510

anchor.surface_text: Vide Lake v. Simmons 1927 A. C. 487 at 510. highly technical rule of English criminal law which had its origin in a legal fiction devised by English Judges to punish a thief, who would otherwise have escaped companyviction, into the provisions of the Indian Sale of Goods Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: conflict of opinion noted by Lord Sumner

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view taken in Folkes v. King 3   is the proper view to take and if, as was said by Scrutton L.
